A 'Petri dish' (or 'Petri plate' or 'cell culture dish') is a shallow glass or
plastic cylindrical lidded dish that biologists use to culture cells
or small moss plants. Ralf Reski (1998): Development, genetics and molecular
biology of mosses. Botanica Acta 111, pp 1â15. It was named after German
bacteriologist Julius Richard
Petri, [http://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/Petri+dish
Petri dish] in the American Heritage Dictionary who invented it when
working as an assistant to Robert Koch. Glass Petri dishes can be reused by
sterilization (for example, in an autoclave or by dry heating in a hot air oven
at 160 Â°C for one hour). For experiments where cross-contamination from one
experiment to the next can become a problem, plastic Petri dishes are often used
as disposables.

Modern Petri dishes often have rings on the lids and bases, which allow them to
be stacked so that they do not slide off one another. Multiple dishes can also
be incorporated into one plastic container to create what is called a "multi-
well plate". Petri dishes are usually used to culture bacteria.
